title.narrative: Great Apes Conservation Fund

description.narrative: Strengthing leadership for conservation in Sierra Leone and Liberia through Research and Training on the Western Chimpanzee

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Great Apes Conservation Fund

description.narrative: This purpose of this project is to: 1) train and mentor a team of professionals for effective leadership in wildlife conservation; 2) establish a foundation for Chimpanzee conservation at Njala University; and 3) facilitate exchanges between conservation professionals in Sierra Leone and Liberia. The Chimpanzee is symbolic of the overall conservation dilemma in West Africa habitat fragmentation, bushmeat hunting, pet trade, and conflicts with humans that require innovative leaders for implementing effective and successful long-term solutions. Activities include: 1) Developing a team of wildlife conservation professionals by designing, organizing and implementing an 18-month MENTOR-CHIMP program on wildlife conservation and management through a combination of lectures, field work, team pilot projects and on-the-job training, and recruiting the team of eight working professionals (Fellows) from Sierra Leone and Liberia for dynamic mentoring by faculty members; 2) Establishing a Foundation for Chimpanzee Research and Monitoring at Njala University to facilitate long-term influence on research and academic training in Wildlife Conservation and Management; identifying long-term priorities for Chimpanzee conservation; mobilizing and engaging Njala University Staff; and establishing partnerships and institutional links; 3) Facilitating exchange visits between professionals in Sierra Leone and Liberia through engagement of Njala University faculty with counterparts at Cuttington University and the University of Liberia. As part of the Cooperative Agreement, USFWS will provide hands-on participation in strategic planning for the new MENTOR-CHIMP program; participate in regular communications; identify potential contacts and provide background on similar programs; provide technical assistance and oversight to the program; participate in the Program Committee; advise on the curriculum design and field implementation projects; review criteria and participate in selectio

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Monitoring, Evaluation and Learning from the MENTOR Programs to Strengthen Conservation Leadership in the African Rainforest

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to evaluate the progress of the USFWS MENTOR (Mentoring for ENvironmental Training in Outreach and Resource conservation) Program which brings together teams of emerging conservation leaders and combines academic and field-based training, long-term mentoring, learning through experience, and project design and implementation to address major threats facing wildlife populations. Specific activities include: (1) assessment of training, capacity development, mentoring, and teamwork within and across the MENTOR projects; (2) advancement of African conservation leadership; and (3) identification of opportunities for collaboration on priority conservation actions and adaptive learning across the MENTOR projects.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund
Agency for International Development, Development Assistance

title.narrative: Continued Development of a Community-Based Marine Turtle Conservation Program for Sierra Leone and Leatherback Conservation Initiative at Turtle, Bonthe/Sherbro Islands and the Southern Shoreline

description.narrative: Production of education/sensitization materials including calendars, brochures and the reproduction of documents that protect marine turtles in Sierra Leone. Coastal community education/sensitization campaign about the conservation of marine turtles. Training workshops for new turtle task force members on marine turtle species identification, tagging and data collection, as well as for law enforcement personnel. Evaluation of the nesting status and hatching success of the five species of marine turtles on Sherbro and Turtle Islands, Turners Peninsula and the mainland beaches surveyed by the project. Evaluation of the by-catch status of the five species of marine turtles on Sherbro and turtle Islands, Turners Peninsula and the mainland communities surveyed by the project. Community development programs within selected fishing communities including the Turtle and Sherbro islands, Turners Peninsula and the mainland coastal communities. Incorporating university students/interns into project activities in order to strengthen the building of a stable future for the project.

activity-date.narrative: Date unavailable. Calculated start date is the earliest transaction date

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund
U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Continued Development of a Community-Based Marine Turtle Conservation Program for Sierra Leone and Leatherback Conservation Initiative at Turtle, Bonthe/Sherbro Islands and the Southern Shoreline

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to develop a marine turtle conservation program within Sierra Leon that will develop on the ground conservation projects and will raise awareness about the threats from poaching and accidental bycatch in fisheries to the depleted sea turtle populations. It is the intent that this project will provide leadership in organizing and implementing sea turtle conservation programs with the national government and local communities to protect and recovery sea turtle nesting populations within Sierra Leone. Activities include: 1) community based nesting beach patrols in the Turtle Islands, Sherbro Island and Turner's Peninsula to patrol nesting beaches during November April to protect nests and nesting females from poaching, 2) collaboration with artisanal fisherman to monitor bycatch and provide training for safe release of captured turtles, and 3) conduct community outreach and education programs in coastal communities and national awareness campaigns about the protected status of sea turtles and their conservation needs.

activity-date.narrative: Date unavailable. Calculated start date is the earliest transaction date

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Loma Mountains National Park Conservation Project. An approach to protect the largest populations of Western Chimpanzee in Sierra Leone

description.narrative: The purpose of this 1-year project is to protect western chimpanzees and other key species in Sierra Leone by implementing a conservation management program in Loma Mountains National Park. Activities include: 1) conducting surveys to estimate chimpanzee abundance and assess local resource usage; 2) implementing Spatial Monitoring and Reporting Tool (SMART) to monitor biodiversity and anthropogenic pressures; 3) strengthening law enforcement through guard training and operationalizing patrols; 4) developing sustainable revenue channels; 5) establishing a basic tourism program, revenue management and revenue sharing procedures; 6); engaging communities in developing tree nurseries for habitat restoration; 7) educating communities on chimpanzee biology and potential societal benefits, and on hunting and resource use regulations; and 8) implementing sustainable alternative livelihoods activities.

activity-date.narrative: Date unavailable. Calculated start date is the earliest transaction date

description.narrative: THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO DEVELOP A MARINE TURTLE CONSERVATION PROGRAM WITHIN SIERRA LEONE THAT WILL DEVELOP ON THE 1 GROUND CONSERVATION PROJECTS AND WILL RAISE AWARENESS ABOUT THE THREATS FROM POACHING AND ACCIDENTAL BYCATCH IN FISHERIES ON DEPLETED SEA TURTLE POPULATIONS. ACTIVITIES INCLUDE (1) COMMUNITY BASED NESTING BEACH SURVEYS IN THE TURTLE ISLANDS, SHERBRO ISLAND AND TURNER S PENINSULA TO SURVEY NESTING BEACHES DURING NOVEMBER TO APRIL TO PROTECT NESTS AND NESTING FEMALES FROM POACHING (2) COLLABORATION WITH ARTISANAL FISHERS TO MONITOR BYCATCH AND PROVIDE TRAINING FOR SAFE RELEASE OF CAPTURED TURTLES AND (3) CONDUCT COMMUNITY OUTREACH AND EDUCATION PROGRAMS IN COASTAL COMMUNITIES AND NATIONAL AWARENESS CAMPAIGNS ABOUT THE PROTECTED STATUS OF SEA TURTLES AND THEIR CONSERVATION NEEDS.

Activities include: (1) community-based nesting beach surveys in the Turtle Islands, Sherbro.Island and Turner's Peninsula to survey nesting beaches during November to April to protect nests and nesting females from.poaching; (2) collaboration with artisanal fishers to monitor bycatch and provide training for safe release of captured turtles; and.(3) conduct community outreach and education programs in coastal communities and national awareness campaigns about the.protected status of sea turtles and their conservation needs.

title.narrative: LOMA MOUNTAINS NATIONAL PARK CONSERVATION PROJECT: AN APPROACH TO PROTECT THE LARGEST POPULATIONS OF WESTERN CHIMPANZEE IN SIERRA LEONE-2

description.narrative: THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO SUPPORT THE PROTECTION OF LOMA MOUNTAINS NATIONAL PARK S ENDANGERED CHIMPANZEES BY (1) CONDUCTING SURVEYS TO ESTIMATE CHIMPANZEE ABUNDANCE, UNDERSTAND POPULATION DYNAMICS, AND IDENTIFY CULTURAL TRAITS (2) CONDUCTING FECAL ANALYSIS AND BOTANICAL SURVEYS TO DETERMINE CHIMPANZEE DIETARY HABITS, AND RESOURCE NEEDS AND USE (3) USING BOTANICAL SURVEYS, SATELLITE IMAGERY AND GROUND TRUTHING TO MAP CHIMPANZEE HABITAT (4) RESTORING THAT HABITAT THROUGH REFORESTATION WITH KEY TREE SPECIES (5) IMPROVING BIOMONITORING THROUGH INCREASING THE NUMBER OF COMMUNITY MONITORS AND EXPANDING THEIR TRAINING (6) CONDUCTING ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION IN 14 SCHOOLS AND INTRODUCING A ROOTS AND SHOOTS PROGRAM FOR REGIONAL YOUTH (7) IMPROVING UNDERSTANDING OF LOCAL ECONOMIES THROUGH A SOCIOECONOMIC STUDY AND LAND USE PLANNING AND PROMOTING A SHIFT TO MORE ENVIRONMENTALLY FRIENDLY LIVELIHOODS.

title.narrative: PREVENTING A LETHAL BACTERIAL DISEASE IN THE CHIMPANZEES OF SIERRA LEONE

description.narrative: THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO GENERATE CRITICAL INFORMATION ON THE ECOLOGY AND BIOLOGY OF A BACTERIUM RESPONSIBLE FOR AN EMERGING AND POSSIBLY ZOONOTIC DISEASE (EPIZOOTIC NEUROLOGIC AND GASTROENTERIC SYNDROME, ENGS) KILLING CRITICALLY ENDANGERED CHIMPANZEES AT A SANCTUARY IN SIERRA LEONE, AND TO ASSESS THE THREAT TO WILD APES BY: (1) CONDUCTING ECOLOGICAL STUDIES TO DETERMINE THE SOURCE OF INFECTION, EXPLAIN SEASONAL PATTERNS OF MORTALITY, AND IDENTIFY CRITICAL MANAGEMENT-RELATED INTERVENTIONS FOR STOPPING THE SPREAD OF THE DISEASE (2) DETERMINING HOW WIDESPREAD THE BACTERIUM AND SYNDROME ARE IN EQUATORIAL AFRICAN SANCTUARIES AND IN THE WILD AND (3) DETERMINING OPTIMAL GROWTH CONDITIONS FOR THE BACTERIUM IN THE LABORATORY TO FACILITATE FUTURE INVESTIGATIONS OF TREATMENTS AND PREVENTIONS.

activity-date.narrative: Date unavailable. Calculated start date is the earliest transaction date

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: LOMA MOUNTAINS NATIONAL PARK CONSERVATION PROJECT: AN APPROACH TO PROTECT THE LARGEST POPULATIONS OF WESTERN CHIMPANZEE IN SIERRA LEONE-2

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to support the protection of Loma Mountains National Parks endangered.chimpanzees by: (1) conducting surveys to estimate chimpanzee abundance, understand population.dynamics, and identify cultural traits; (2) conducting fecal analysis and botanical surveys to determine.chimpanzee dietary habits, and resource needs and use; (3) using botanical surveys, satellite imagery and.ground-truthing to map chimpanzee habitat; (4) restoring that habitat through reforestation with key tree.species; (5) improving biomonitoring through increasing the number of community monitors and.expanding their training; (6) conducting environmental education in 14 schools and introducing a Roots.& Shoots program for regional youth; (7) improving understanding of local economies through a.socioeconomic study and land use planning; and promoting a shift to more environmentally friendly.livelihoods.

activity-date.narrative: Date unavailable. Calculated start date is the earliest transaction date

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: PREVENTING A LETHAL BACTERIAL DISEASE IN THE CHIMPANZEES OF SIERRA LEONE

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to generate critical information on the ecology and biology of a bacterium.responsible for an emerging and possibly zoonotic disease (Epizootic Neurologic and Gastroenteric.Syndrome, ENGS) killing critically endangered chimpanzees at a sanctuary in Sierra Leone, and to assess.the threat to wild apes by: (1) conducting ecological studies to determine the source of infection, explain.seasonal patterns of mortality, and identify critical management-related interventions for stopping the.spread of the disease; (2) determining how widespread the bacterium and syndrome are in Equatorial.African sanctuaries and in the wild; and (3) determining optimal growth conditions for the bacterium in.the laboratory to facilitate future investigations of treatments and preventions.

activity-date.narrative: Date unavailable. Calculated start date is the earliest transaction date

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry
